website_summaries.verdict: A great budget belay device from one of the best brands in the industry.
pros: A durable device that will last for years
Requires very little force to hold a heavier climber so it's great if you're climbing with a partner who is significantly larger than you
cons: Not as smooth for belaying as it is for repelling

customer_reviews.title: I dig it
customer_reviews.text: Works great with my 10.5mm rope. Slow descents which I prefer. Nice anodized finish too. No issues to report at this time 🤙
customer_reviews.author: Gabe

customer_reviews.title: Simple, Inexpensive, Functional, and Light.  What's not to love?
customer_reviews.text: Simple, inexpensive, functional, and light. What's not to love? And it works with both the 11+mm gym ropes you are likely to encounter as well as 9mm lead climbing ropes. I also own an XP Guide and much prefer the ATC XP for gym use. The rope slots in the Guide are narrower for some reason and it does not work well with fat gym ropes. So unless you actually intend to top belay someone, this is what you want.

customer_reviews.title: Roof safety!

customer_reviews.title: works well. Lacks durability
customer_reviews.text: I've been climbing (trad) for over 30 years, and have had many different belay devices. This one really works well, as far as feeding rope out quickly and providing a good/easy catch. Rappelling works fine as well. I can already tell it is going to wear out quickly though. As soon as the "teeth" area smoothes out some, some of the above mentioned features will go away. They didn't have to make it so light. 10 grams heavier would probably make it last twice as long, and not get as hot when you rappel.
